linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 1 shows the large areal variations in the dominant semidiurnal M2 and dirnal K1 components. Moreover there are two semidiurnal amphidromic points (position of zero amplitude) near 25°N 53°E and 28°N 50°E, and a single amphidromic point for the diurnal tide near 51°N 27°E. This has a profound impact on the nature of the tide in the Gulf. Tides are classified by using the ratio of the amplitudes of the main diurnal constituents K1 and O1 to that of the two main semi-diurnal amplitudes M2 and S2 known as the “form ratio”.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Co-range maps in cm (a), (c) and co-tidal maps (b), (d) in degree for tidal component M2 (resp. K1) in the Gulf (from Pous et al. 2012).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Co-range maps in cm (a), (c) and co-tidal maps (b), (d) in degree for tidal component M2 (resp. K1) in the Gulf (from Pous et al. 2012).

linkTarget.bib:
Pous et al., 2012
S. Pous , X. Carton , and P. Lazure
2012. A Process Study of the Tidal Circulation in the Persian Gulf. Open Journal of Marine Science , 2: 131 140 . http://dx.doi.org/10.4236/ojms.2012.24016.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Defant (1961) gives the following classification for categorizing the type of tide: semi-diurnal for F < 0.25; mixed, mainly semi-diurnal for F between 0.25 and 1.5; mixed, mainly diurnal for F between 1.5 and 3.0; and diurnal for F > 3.0. According to Figure 2 the tide is generally mixed except close to the semidiurnal points where the tide is diurnal and close to the diurnal amphidromic point where the tide is semidiurnal.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Map of the form ratio (from Pous et al. 2012

formatted-caption.caption-text: Map of the form ratio (from Pous et al. 2012

2012. A Process Study of the Tidal Circulation in the Persian Gulf. Open Journal of Marine Science , 2: 131 140 . http://dx.doi.org/10.4236/ojms.2012.24016.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Field A is very close to the diurnal amphidromic and experiences only one tide per day (F=3.5). This is clearly evident from bottomhole pressure measurements (Figure 3). Spectral analysis of the detrended pressure from well#1 test#4 (Figure 4) reveals a strong diurnal component and a very weak semidiurnal. Tidal recordings are available from 3 stations: Zirku, M1 and Al Mubarraz some 40 to 80 km from Field A The harmonic analysis of these stations was conducted by Poux et al. (Table 2). The tide type changes drastically from being mixed at M1 and Al Mubarraz to diurnal at Zirku while the amplitude of M2 decreases from 31 cm to 11 cm. In order to capture this trend, the harmonic constituents, both ampltides and phases, were linearly interpolated to Field A (Figure 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Detrended bottomhole pressure (raw and smoothed) at well#1 test#4 during November 1991 (top) and predicted water levels at four locations during the same period (bottom).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Detrended bottomhole pressure (raw and smoothed) at well#1 test#4 during November 1991 (top) and predicted water levels at four locations during the same period (bottom).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Detrended bottomhole pressure (raw and smoothed) at well#1 test#4 during November 1991
predicted water levels at four locations during the same period

Spectral analysis of the detrended pressure from well#1 test#4 (Figure 4) reveals a strong diurnal component and a very weak semidiurnal. Tidal recordings are available from 3 stations: Zirku, M1 and Al Mubarraz some 40 to 80 km from Field A The harmonic analysis of these stations was conducted by Poux et al. (Table 2). The tide type changes drastically from being mixed at M1 and Al Mubarraz to diurnal at Zirku while the amplitude of M2 decreases from 31 cm to 11 cm. In order to capture this trend, the harmonic constituents, both ampltides and phases, were linearly interpolated to Field A (Figure 5).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Field A is very close to the diurnal amphidromic and experiences only one tide per day (F=3.5). This is clearly evident from bottomhole pressure measurements (Figure 3). Spectral analysis of the detrended pressure from well#1 test#4 (Figure 4) reveals a strong diurnal component and a very weak semidiurnal. Tidal recordings are available from 3 stations: Zirku, M1 and Al Mubarraz some 40 to 80 km from Field A The harmonic analysis of these stations was conducted by Poux et al. (Table 2). The tide type changes drastically from being mixed at M1 and Al Mubarraz to diurnal at Zirku while the amplitude of M2 decreases from 31 cm to 11 cm. In order to capture this trend, the harmonic constituents, both ampltides and phases, were linearly interpolated to Field A (Figure 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Surface trends of M2 and K1 amplitudes.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Surface trends of M2 and K1 amplitudes.

linkTarget.anchoringText: It is not until 1994 that the first electronic gauges were deployed with a resolution of 0.01 psi, suitable for tidal analysis. The tidal removal procedures of Levithan and Phan with the spline model, and Zhao and Reynolds with the two log model were tested on some build-ups and interference tests. Some of the responses are complex with early pressure build-up followed by depletion from interfering wells (Figure 6) or depletion followed by repressurization after shutting neighbouring wells (Figure 7). The two log model is inappropriate to fit this non-monotonous behavior. Also the spline model would require switching from logarithmically spaced nodes to uniform nodes on a case by case basis which is cumbersome.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Steps 1 to 3 applied to build-up well#1 test#4 (top) and steps 4 to 6 (bottom).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Steps 1 to 3 applied to build-up well#1 test#4 (top) and steps 4 to 6 (bottom).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Steps 1 to 3 applied to build-up well#1 test#4

linkTarget.anchoringText: It is not until 1994 that the first electronic gauges were deployed with a resolution of 0.01 psi, suitable for tidal analysis. The tidal removal procedures of Levithan and Phan with the spline model, and Zhao and Reynolds with the two log model were tested on some build-ups and interference tests. Some of the responses are complex with early pressure build-up followed by depletion from interfering wells (Figure 6) or depletion followed by repressurization after shutting neighbouring wells (Figure 7). The two log model is inappropriate to fit this non-monotonous behavior. Also the spline model would require switching from logarithmically spaced nodes to uniform nodes on a case by case basis which is cumbersome.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Steps 1 to 3 applied to interference well#1 test#2 (top) and steps 4 to 6 (bottom).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Steps 1 to 3 applied to interference well#1 test#2 (top) and steps 4 to 6 (bottom).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Steps 1 to 3 applied to interference well#1 test#2

linkTarget.anchoringText: Field A is located in the Gulf approximatively 130 km north-west of Abu Dhabi. The reservoir is a gentle anticline (Figure 8) and sits at a depth of 5500 ft subsea. It consists of alternating sedimentary cycles of porous and dense chalky limestone. The formation is subdivided into 3 main producing porous layers from top to bottom: L1, L2 and L3 (Figure 9). The reservoir quality improves overall from L1 to L3, with good matrix porosity ranging from 15 to 25% and a low matrix permeability ranging from 0.1 to 7 mD enhanced by the presence of open fractures in certain places.

Field A is located in the Gulf approximatively 130 km north-west of Abu Dhabi. The reservoir is a gentle anticline (Figure 8) and sits at a depth of 5500 ft subsea. It consists of alternating sedimentary cycles of porous and dense chalky limestone. The formation is subdivided into 3 main producing porous layers from top to bottom: L1, L2 and L3 (Figure 9). The reservoir quality improves overall from L1 to L3, with good matrix porosity ranging from 15 to 25% and a low matrix permeability ranging from 0.1 to 7 mD enhanced by the presence of open fractures in certain places.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Typical CPI at the crest with reservoir layering.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Typical CPI at the crest with reservoir layering.

linkTarget.anchoringText: RF is the recovery factor and ΔP the pressure drop. The crossplot in Figure 10 yields a total compressibility of 19×10-6 psi-1 equivalent to an average pore pressure compressibility for the matrix-fracture system of 13×10-6 psi-1.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Crossplot of recovery factor and pressure drop during the early depletion phase.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Crossplot of recovery factor and pressure drop during the early depletion phase.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Table 3 summarises the PTA and tidal analysis. We notice from Figure 11 an increasing trend of tidal efficiency with KH from 0.08 to 0.24. Indeed the diffusive fractures improve the matrix KH, typically by a factor of 10, while fracture corridors enhance it by more than 100. Thus high KH is indicative of fractures near the well. These fractures increase the rock compressibility and produce a higher tidal efficiency (Equation 3). Also flank wells well#5, 6 and 7 have higher tidal efficiencies than wells with similar KH at the crest.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Fluid and fracture effects on tidal efficiency.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Fluid and fracture effects on tidal efficiency.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Pore pressure compressibility measured on cores varied from 2.0×10-6 psi-1 for to 2.7×10-6 psi-1 for porosities variying from 10% to 22% respectively. In the matrix and diffuse fracture region, the average pore volume compressibility from tidal efficiency is 2.0×10-6 psi-1, which is close to the experimental value (Figure 12). In the fracture corridor region, the calculate pore volume compressibility increases to an average of 2.7×10-6 psi-1.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Crossplot of pore pressure compressibility from tidal analysis and interpreted KH.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Crossplot of pore pressure compressibility from tidal analysis and interpreted KH.
